name: The Original Four
description: The four women who founded Mount Sinai
long_description:
In August of 1913, four immigrant women from Toronto's Jewish community started knocking on neighbourhood doors to raise money for a hospital.

The Jewish immigrant population in Toronto was burgeoning; most of the new immigrants didn't speak English and were afraid of large institutions. And, sadly, not a hospital in the city would give Jewish doctors a place to practice.

It took them nine years, but by 1922, the Mrs. Cohn, Miller, Spiegel and Adler had raised $12,000, enough to buy a building at 100 Yorkville.

Instructions: There are 3 caches, each cache contains a number. Enter that number below and it will reveal the location of the next cache. Finding all 3 will unlock a special prize!

name: Dorothy Dworkin
description: One of the original founders of Mount Sinai
long_description:
Dorothy Dworkin was born to Wolf and Sara Goldstick in Windau, in the Courland Governorate of the Russian Empire (present-day Latvia). She had six sisters and four brothers. In 1904, she immigrated with her family to Canada.

In 1907, she chose to become a maternity nurse. She spent a year working under Dr. Kaufman and various of his colleagues until Dr. Kaufman suggested that she go to train at Mount Sinai Hospital, Cleveland, where she would train as a midwife. Prior to leaving Toronto, she helped establish a free Jewish Dispensary located at Elizabeth Street near Agnes, which is now Dundas Street, with Ida Siegel and her brother Abe Lewis. She was the dispensary's first nurse. In 1909, she received a diploma from the Medical State Board of Ohio.

Instructions: There are 3 caches, each cache contains a number. Enter that number below and it will reveal the location of the next cache. Finding all 3 will unlock a special prize!

name: James William Bridgland
description: The builder and owner of 100 Yorkville Avenue.
long_description:
In 1922, a location at 100 Yorkville Avenue was purchased with $12,000. The two-storey building was built as a private residence in 1871 by James D. Bridgland, the Crown's Inspector of Roads; in 1914, the home was converted into the Lyndhurst Private Hospital.

When Jewish doctors were not welcome in non-Jewish hospitals; 100 Yorkville provided communication in Yiddish, kosher food for patients. The hospital moved to its present location on University Avenue in 1953.

Instructions: There are 3 caches, each cache contains a number. Enter that number below and it will reveal the location of the next cache. Finding all 3 will unlock a special prize!

name: The Ezra Noshem Society
description: A Society of Women Behind Funding
long_description:
The Ezras Noshem Society (or Ezras Noshim Society) was a women's mutual benefit society established in Toronto in 1913 by R. Miller, a Mrs. Adler, and a Mrs. Zigerman. It began as an aid organization through which dues-paying members received visits and help with household chores during times of illness. The growing need for a place to care for elderly Jews prompted the society to open the Jewish Old Folks' Home in a house at 31 Cecil Street in 1917. Slova Greenberg initiated this effort and was still leading the Ezras Noshem Society when it played an instrumental role in raising funds for and founding Mount Sinai Hospital on Yorkville Avenue, around 1922.

Instructions: There are 3 caches, each cache contains a number. Enter that number below and it will reveal the location of the next cache. Finding all 3 will unlock a special prize!

name: Heather Reisman
description: First Chair in Perinatal Nursing Research
long_description:
In 1979, Heather Reisman co-founded Paradigm Consulting and served as the managing director of this strategic change consultancy until 1995. In 1995, Reisman founded a company called Indigo Books and Music. She raised $25m from a group of investors based on the original concept document for Indigo. In 2001, Indigo Books and Music acquired its main rival, Chapters, to form the largest book retailer in Canada, obtaining a clear leadership position in the book retailing industry. Reisman co-founded Kobo Inc. in 2009 and two years later, sold Indigo's majority stake in Kobo to the Japanese company Rakuten for $315 million.

Mount Sinai Hospital announced in December 2013 that a transformational $15 million gift from Reisman and Schwartz would be used to 'reshape emergency medicine' at the facility. In 1996, as a result of a partnership with the University of Toronto, Mount Sinai establishes the Heather M. Reisman Chair in Perinatal Nursing Research, Canada's first endowed chair for nursing research.

Instructions: There are 3 caches, each cache contains a number. Enter that number below and it will reveal the location of the next cache. Finding all 3 will unlock a special prize!

name: Dr. Allan Gross
description: Orthopaedic surgeon at Mount Sinai Hospital
long_description:
An orthopaedic surgeon specializing in lower extremity reconstruction, with a particular interest in revision arthroplasty of the hip and knee. Has published extensively on the use of allograft bone in revision arthoplasty of the hip and knee. Has the largest series in the world of fresh osteochondral allografts performed for post traumatic defects of the knee. Supervises a large institutional tissue bank and comprehensive orthopaedic transplant programme.

Dr. Allan Gross and his team perform Canada's first fresh tissue hip transplant. Five years later, his team performs Canada's first knee joint transplant.

name: Monty Maurice Simmonds
long_description:
As chairman of the Mount Sinai Hospital, in the late 70's Monty oversaw the construction of the new building on University Avenue and had the honour of welcoming Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip to its opening in 1974. It was Mr. Simmonds direct and (at times controversial) method of doing business that accelerated the construction of the new building. In 1986, the statue 'Valerie' by Jack Culiner was installed in Mount Sinai in honour of Mr.Simmonds sister Valerie.

Thank you to Judy Simmonds for permitting the usage of her farm for the commemoration of her husband.

name: Sidney Liswood
description: Former Executive Director of Mount Sinai
long_description:
Mr. Sidney Liswood, the executive director of Mount Sinai Hospital from 1954 to 1973. The Sidney Liswood Health Sciences Library opened at its present location on University Avenue in 1974.

Working with Monty Maurice Simmonds, Mr. Liswood oversaw the construction of the New Mount Sinai hospital on University Avenue. Mr Liswood helped setup programs, still in use to this day, that train health administrators.

Instructions: There are 3 caches, each cache contains a number. Enter that number below and it will reveal the location of the next cache. Finding all 3 will unlock a special prize!

name: Allan Rudolph
description: Current Board Chair of the Circle of Care
long_description:
Allan Rudolph is the Chief Board of Directors of the Circle of Care within the Sinai Health Systems. He is also a Managing Partner at BDO and is a member of the Toronto Region Management Board. Allan's area of specialization includes manufacturing and retail. He also has extensive experience in multi-location audits, working with high profile clients. Allan is an active member of various firm committees and has also been involved in a number of charitable organizations including Circle of Care. Allan sits on the Sinai Health board as an ex-officio member.

Allan oversaw more than 16,000 clients and caregivers leaned on Circle of Care for supports and services that allow them to live independently at home.
